children.subject: For what it's worth, I've never gotten an OS question in an interview.

Honest question, but if you haven't taken 162 yet but you aspire to be a SWE, what else do you think is more interesting? I assume the you've probably taken the usual 186 and 161 that people do before 162. I'm also gonna assume you haven't taken the more "hardcore" systems classes like 164 and 151.

If you're expecting OS questions in interviews, it seems like you're going to be a backend engineer. Then if that's case, I don't really understand why you're pursuing this career if you're not hyped about systems to begin with.

history.content:
Unlike those below, I received quite a few questions from various software companies like 2Sigma, Uber, etc. 

One question I received was what's the difference between a process and a thread? Why would you use one over the other? 

This is an answer that should be drilled into your brain after having taken 162.

Another question I received was describing how to implementing a server using a bounded thread pool. This is part of a 162 project.

162 has been very effective with me in terms of interview questions.

children.subject: I think 162 is worth to take. It may comes up a bit in the interviews (process vs thread, multithreading). It also gives you a very good foundation to work in system area, such as cloud.

history.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm a little unsure about taking CS162 this fall. I'm currently a senior who has the units to graduate this semester and I've heard that Operating Systems is a really useful class to take. However, there's a lot of other more interesting CS/EECS classes that I want to check out and I'm not really sure if CS162 would be worth my time, especially given the workload. As I'll be recruiting in the fall, I also want to give myself lots of time to prep for interviews in addition to my classes. Unfortunately, I've heard that OS questions are quite common in interviews. Am I shooting myself in the foot by pushing it back to the spring? Do recruiters look at the classes you've taken in your resume? Alternatively, I was thinking of doing an online OS course for a rudimentary knowledge of that subject area but I don't know how to put that in my resume. Please let me know your thoughts, thanks!
history.subject: Unsure about CS162 and how it relates to recruiting
